name: Scratch Animation Project
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals
use sequence, selection, and repetition in programs
pedagogical_rationale: Scratch is the de facto standard block-based programming environment for primary computing. Creating an animation requires sequencing, repetition (loops for animation), and event handling -- three key NC concepts in a single motivating project. The visual output gives immediate feedback on whether code is working correctly. This is typically the first substantial Scratch project at KS2.
common_pitfalls: Too ambitious a first project -- start with one sprite doing one thing
Not using the green flag event block -- programs do not run without a trigger
Repeat loops set to wrong numbers -- test with small numbers first

name: Scratch Interactive Quiz
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals
use sequence, selection, and repetition in programs; work with variables and various forms of input and output
pedagogical_rationale: An interactive quiz introduces selection (if-then-else) and variables (score tracking). The quiz asks a question, checks the answer using an if-block, and updates the score -- a complete input-process-output cycle. Creating quiz content on any subject reinforces cross-curricular knowledge. Variables are introduced naturally as 'the score counter'.
common_pitfalls: Answer comparison is case-sensitive -- teach 'lowercase both' or accept multiple spellings
Score variable not initialised to 0 at the start -- teach reset at program start
Questions all asked at once without waiting for input -- teach the 'ask and wait' block

name: Scratch Game Design
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals
solve problems by decomposing them into smaller parts
pedagogical_rationale: Designing a game in Scratch is the most motivating KS2 programming project and the one that demands the most sophisticated programming. A simple maze game requires all three control structures (sequence, selection, repetition), variables (lives, score, timer), and decomposition (separate scripts for player movement, enemy movement, collision detection, scoring). The project naturally teaches decomposition because it is too complex to write as a single script.
common_pitfalls: Starting with the game and not the plan -- require a design document before coding
All code in one sprite -- teach that each sprite manages its own behaviour
Not playtesting -- games need testing by someone other than the creator

name: Networks and the Internet
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: understand computer networks including the internet; how they can provide multiple services, such as the world wide web; and the opportunities they offer for communication and collaboration
use search technologies effectively, appreciate how results are selected and ranked, and be discerning in evaluating digital content
pedagogical_rationale: Understanding how the internet works is foundational to digital literacy and online safety. Pupils learn that the internet is a physical network of connected devices, that data travels in packets, and that the World Wide Web is one service running on the internet (alongside email, streaming, etc.). Role-play activities where pupils act as routers, servers, and clients make the abstract infrastructure tangible. The unit sequence explicitly targets three misconceptions: web is not the internet, the internet is not a 'place', and data does not travel as one continuous blob.
common_pitfalls: Conflating 'the internet' with 'the web' -- explicitly distinguish infrastructure from service
Too abstract -- use physical role-play: pupils pass paper 'packets' to each other
Not connecting to safety -- 'now you know how data travels, what happens to your personal information?'
Research activity degenerates into poster-making without knowledge check
Vocabulary mat left blank -- every core term must have a pupil-safe definition

vocabulary_mat.definition: Connected devices that can share data and resources.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Our classroom computers and printer are on a network.
The internet connects millions of networks all over the world.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A service on the internet made of linked web pages.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: When you visit a website, you are using the World Wide Web.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A collection of web pages under one address.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: The BBC website has pages about news, sport, and weather.

vocabulary_mat.definition: An app used to view web pages.
A computer that stores and sends data such as websites.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: When you visit a website, a server sends the page to your computer.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A device that directs packets between networks.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: A router decides which way to send data, like a postman choosing a route.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A small chunk of data sent across a network.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: An email is broken into packets before it travels across the internet.

vocabulary_mat.definition: Agreed rules for sending and receiving data.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Protocols make sure packets arrive correctly, like rules for posting a letter.

vocabulary_mat.definition: The address of a web page.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: You type a URL into the browser to visit a website.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A clickable link to another page or resource.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Click the hyperlink to go to a different web page.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A tool that finds and ranks web pages.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Google is a search engine that helps you find information.

vocabulary_mat.definition: A number label that identifies a device on a network.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Every computer on the internet has its own IP address, like a house number.

vocabulary_mat.definition: How much data can be sent at once.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: A video call needs more bandwidth than sending a text message.

vocabulary_mat.definition: Information stored or sent by computers.
vocabulary_mat.example_sentence: Photos, messages, and web pages are all types of data.

statutory_decomposition.requirement: multiple services, such as the world wide web
appreciate how results are selected and ranked
be discerning in evaluating digital content

assessment_items.stem: The web is the same as the internet: True or False? Explain.
assessment_items.expected: False. The internet is the global network of networks. The web is one service that runs on the internet.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: Internet and web are the same thing

assessment_items.stem: Email is part of the web: True or False? Explain.
assessment_items.expected: False. Email uses the internet but is a separate service from the web.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: All internet services are the web

assessment_items.stem: A network is: (A) one computer (B) connected computers sharing data (C) the internet.
Label the client, server, and router on this network diagram.
assessment_items.expected: Client = device requesting data. Server = device storing/serving data. Router = device directing packets between networks.

assessment_items.stem: Packets can take different routes and still arrive: True or False.
assessment_items.expected: True. Routers choose the best route for each packet. They are reassembled at the destination.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: Data travels as one continuous piece

assessment_items.stem: Data always travels as one long piece: True or False.
assessment_items.expected: False. Data is split into packets, and different packets may take different routes.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: Data travels as one continuous piece

assessment_items.stem: A pupil says: 'The internet is inside my computer.' What would you say to help them understand?
assessment_items.expected: The internet is not inside any computer. It is a network of networks connecting millions of devices. Your computer connects to the internet through a router.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: The internet is inside my computer

assessment_items.stem: Explain 'packet' and 'protocol' in your own words.
assessment_items.expected: A packet is a small chunk of data. A protocol is a set of rules that computers follow to send and receive packets correctly.

assessment_items.stem: You find three websites about routers. One is from a computer science teacher, one is from an advert for a router shop, one has no author. Which is most reliable? Why?
assessment_items.expected: The computer science teacher's site is most reliable because the author has expertise and no commercial motive. The shop advert is biased. The anonymous site cannot be verified.
assessment_items.misconception_targeted: Everything on the internet is true

name: Data Handling with Spreadsheets
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: select, use and combine a variety of software on a range of digital devices to design and create a range of programs, systems and content that accomplish given goals
pedagogical_rationale: Spreadsheets teach data handling in a computing context -- entering data, creating formulae, and generating charts. This connects computing to mathematics (data handling) and science (recording results). Pupils learn that software can process data automatically, which is the conceptual bridge to understanding what computers actually do -- process information according to rules.
common_pitfalls: Treating the spreadsheet as a table for typing in -- teach formulae as the point, not just cells
Formulae errors from wrong cell references -- teach cell naming and checking
Charts without titles or labels -- teach that data presentation requires context

name: Online Safety: Digital Footprint and Cyberbullying
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: use technology safely, respectfully and responsibly; recognise acceptable/unacceptable behaviour; identify a range of ways to report concerns about content and contact
pedagogical_rationale: KS2 online safety deepens the KS1 foundations with two critical concepts: digital footprint (everything you do online leaves a trace that is potentially permanent and public) and cyberbullying (recognising it, not participating in it, and knowing how to respond). Age 8-11 is when most children first encounter social media through family devices, making these concepts urgently practical.
common_pitfalls: Scare-based teaching that makes children afraid of the internet -- balance risk awareness with positive use
Assuming children will not encounter these issues until secondary school -- many already have
Not involving parents -- the school message must be reinforced at home

name: HTML: My First Web Page
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals
select, use and combine a variety of software on a range of digital devices to design and create a range of programs, systems and content that accomplish given goals
pedagogical_rationale: HTML introduces text-based coding in a forgiving context -- mistakes produce visible but non-catastrophic results (a tag in the wrong place makes text look wrong, not crash a program). Creating a web page is inherently meaningful: every website they use is made of HTML. Pupils see the direct relationship between code (text) and output (rendered page). This prepares for text-based programming languages.
common_pitfalls: Forgetting closing tags -- teach the 'open, content, close' pattern
Spelling errors in tags -- HTML tags must be exact; teach careful typing
Spending all time on content and no time on structure -- focus on tags and structure first, then content

name: Micro:bit Physical Computing
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals, including controlling or simulating physical systems
pedagogical_rationale: The micro:bit bridges digital programming and the physical world. Pupils program the micro:bit to respond to sensor inputs (button press, tilt, light level, temperature) and produce outputs (LED display, sound). This physical computing connects to DT (control in products) and Science (sensors measuring the environment). The block-based editor makes it accessible while the physical output makes it tangible.
common_pitfalls: Too many features at once -- start with one input and one output
Not downloading the program to the micro:bit -- test on the simulator first, then download
USB connection issues -- teach the download-and-transfer process explicitly

name: Introduction to Python
subject: Computing
curriculum_reference: design, write and debug programs that accomplish specific goals
use logical reasoning to explain how some simple algorithms work and to detect and correct errors in algorithms and programs
pedagogical_rationale: The NC requires experience of at least one text-based programming language at KS2. Python is the standard choice because its syntax is readable and forgiving, it is used professionally (motivation for older pupils), and it connects directly to KS3 computing. Starting with simple programs (print statements, input, variables, if-else) and building to loops prepares pupils for secondary school programming.
common_pitfalls: Syntax errors causing frustration -- teach that error messages are helpful, not punishing
Typing speed too slow -- accept that text-based coding is slower at first; it develops with practice
Copy-paste without understanding -- require pupils to explain what each line does
